Micaela esta agradecida con los prestamistas kiva ya que gracias a la ayuda brindada podrá realizar algunas mejoras en el cableado de luz de su vivienda, entre otros, de esta manera tener mayor seguridad, asi podrá tener mayor tranquilidad y seguir trabajando para poder hacer realdiad su gran sueño:” Darle una buena educacióna  sus hijos”.
texts.en:
Micaela, 30 years old, lives in the city of Pucallpa and works in a business in her city as an employee. She is the mother of two children who she loves very much and for whom she works very hard to complete the tasks at her job since it is her only source of income to be able to get ahead.

Micaela is grateful to the Kiva lenders since, thanks to the help they are offering her, she will be able to make some improvements in the electrical wiring of her home, among others, and in this way have more safety, and to be able to have more peace and to continue working in order to realize her great dream: to give her children a good education.

loans.use: to repair the wiring.

loans.name: Orlando

texts.es: Orlando es viudo y tiene tres hijos. Orlando vive en La Paz en una casa de ladrillo y cemento que es propia Orlando es jubilado y necesita un credito para hacerse examenes medicos de rutina, a su edad ya debe tener controles regulares para ver su estado en general. Orlando es jubilado y no tiene a nadie que le ayude por eso pide su ayuda
texts.en:
Orlando is a widower who has three children.  He lives in La Paz in his own house, which is made of brick and cement.

Orlando's retired and has nobody to help him, so he's asking for help.  He needs a loan to have routine medical exams.  At his age he should be having regular monitoring to examine his general condition.

loans.use: to have regular medical exams

loans.name: Reninger

texts.es:
Reninger vive en la ciudad de Pucallpa en un distrito de la ciudad al lado de sus padres, quienes le enseñaron el oficio de la agricultura desde pequeño y se dedica a ello desde hace muchos años, lo cual le ha permitido poder salir adelante, ya que es su única fuente de ingresos, actualmente tiene su cultivo de cacao, al cual le brinda mucho cuidado.

Reninger esta agradecido con los prestamistas kiva ya que gracias a la ayuda otorgada podrá solventar los gastos de mantenimiento y abono del cultivo, de esta manera los frutos de cacao crecerán en buen estado y así podrá mejorar sus ingresos ya que tendrá una buena cosecha, de esta manera seguira luchando para hacer realidad su gran sueño:” mejorar su calidad de vida”.
texts.en:
Reninger lives in the city of Pucallpa in a district of the city at his parents' side, who taught him the job of agriculture when he was young and he has worked in this job for many years, which has permitted him to be able to get ahead, since it is his only source of income. Currently he has a cocoa crop, to which he gives great care.

Reninger is grateful to the Kiva lenders since, thanks to the offered help, he will be able to pay the maintenance costs and manure for the crop, and in this way the cocoa fruits will grow to a good state and he will be able to increase his income since he will have a good harvest. So, he will continue fighting to realize his great dream: to improve his quality of life.

loans.use: to pay the costs of manure and the maintenance of the cocoa crop.

loans.name: Virginia Teresa

texts.es:
Virginia vive en la ciudad de Carhuaz, en uno de los distritos de la zona. Virgina tiene un carácter amigable y sobre todo mucha ganas de salir adelante, e spro ello que con mucho esfuerzo y ahorro logro iniciar su negocio de venta de abarrotes, con el cual puede tener ingresos y poder solventar sus gastos de estudio, ya que actualmente cursa la carrera técnica de enfermería en un instituto de su ciudad, actualmente se encuentra en el quinto ciclo y Virginia esta muy contenta, ya que uno de sus sueños es poder tener una profesión y con esfuerzo lo esta logrando.

Virginia esta agradecida con los prestamistas kiva ya que gracias a la ayuda que le han brindado ella podrá solventar algunos gastos de estudio como materiales, utensilios, entre otros, lo que le permitra llevar sus clases con los materiales necesarios y poder estudiar de mejor manera.
texts.en:
Virginia lives in the city of Carhauz, in one of the districts of the region. Virginia has a very friendly character and, above all, much desire to get ahead. For this reason, with much effort and savings, she managed to open her grocery business, with which she can have an income and be able to pay student expenses, since she is currently studying the technical major of nursing at a school in her city. She currently is in the fifth year and Virginia is very happy, since one of her dreams is to be able to have a profession, and with effort, she is achieving this. 

Virginia is grateful to the Kiva lenders since, thanks to the help they are offering her, she will be able to pay some student costs such as materials and supplies among others, which will allow her to bring the necessary materials to class and be able to study better.

loans.use: To pay student expenses (materials and supplies, among others)

loans.name: Tavai Group

texts.es:
Las 18 integrantes de este grupo son mujeres jefas de familia que se han unido para que a través de la lucha de todas juntas puedan salir adelante e ir creciendo.
Una persona digna de destacar es la Sra. Blanca, quien es la presidenta de este grupo, ella es una persona muy activa, que se está esforzando por poder dar a su familia todo lo que ella no pudo tener. Blanca vende verduras en un mercado muy popular, viaja todas las mañanas grandes distancias para poder hacer sus ventas. Comenta que le gustaría poder tener un negocio en su propia ciudad, para no tener que ir muy lejos.
Pide este préstamo para poder comprar tomates, locotes, mandioca, cebolla y demás para poder seguir con su venta, tratando de generar mejores ingresos.
texts.en: The 18 members of this group are mothers who are heads of their families who have gotten together through their every day struggles so they can grow and get ahead. Blanca is one member who stands out and she is the president of the group. She is a very active person who makes the effort to provide for her family everything she could not have. She sells vegetables in a very busy market. She travels a long distance every morning in order to make her sales. She comments that she would have liked to have a business in her own city so she didn't have to travel so far. She is requesting a loan to be able to buy tomatoes, peppers, manioc, onion and others to continue with her sales, trying to generate more revenue.

loans.use: to buy tomatoes, peppers, manioc, onions and other vegetables for resale.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy products to stock her store

loans.name: Maria

texts.es: Maria es soltera pero tiene dos hijos Maria vive con sus padres en La Paz en una casa de ladrillo y cemento que le pertenece a su familia Maria trabaja como encargada de servir el té y otros alimentos a los empleados de una oficina privada María quiere un crédito para comprar provisiones para el servicio de té y también para renovar vajillas Maria es la unica fuente de ingresos en su hogar por lo que necesita su ayuda
texts.en:
María's single but she has two children.  She lives with her parents in La Paz in a house made of brick and cement that belongs to her family.  María is responsible for providing a tea service and other food to the employees of a private office.

María wants a loan to buy provisions for the tea service and also to replace some silverware.

María's the only source of income in her household, so she needs help.

loans.use: to buy provisions for a tea service and to replace silverware

loans.name: Mujeres Trabajadoras Group

texts.es:
El grupo Mujeres Trabajadoras   está en su ciclo número 1 del programa de comité de mujeres, es de la ciudad de Concepción, la cual es una zona una zona alejada de la capital del país que está en crecimiento.
La Sra. Simeona es una de las integrantes, ella es vendedora ambulante de comestibles que ella misma hace y que después sale a vender de manera ambulante. Desea que a través de su trabajo su sacrificio pueda mejorar sus ingresos y ayudar a sus familias.
Solicita este préstamo para la compra de insumos para poder seguir haciendo sus comidas, como ser verduras, condimentos, carne y demás, y de esa forma poder seguir creciendo con su negocio y dar así a su familia lo que necesitan para tener una vida sin privaciones.
texts.en:
The Mujeres Trabajadores (Hard-working Women) group is in its first loan cycle of the women's committee program. It is from the city of Concepción, which is in a region remote from the country's capital, which is growing.

Simeona is one of the members. She is a street vendor of food that she prepares herself, and later leaves to sell on foot. She desires that through her work and sacrifice she can improve her income and help her family members.

She asks for this loan to purchase supplies to continue preparing her food, such as vegetables, seasoning, meat and others, and in this way continue growing with her business and also to give her family what it needs to live a life without deprivation.

loans.use: To purchase vegetables, seasonings, meat and other things to prepare food.

loans.name: Victoria

texts.es:
La socia pertenece al banco comunal “SANTA BEATRIZ”; El banco está ubicado en el distrito de Maranura, perteneciente a la provincia de La Convención y departamento de Cusco.

La socia Victoria  se dedica al negocio de venta de frutas y verduras,la socia vende en el mercado,  la socia vende platanos, naranjas y mandarinas y también vende cebollas, tomates y zapallos, la socia ya tiene varios años en este negocio y le va muy bien, el sueño de la socia es tener un local donde pueda vender las frutas y verduras. La socia solicita el crédito para comprar naranjas, plátanos y mandarinas y compra verduras como cebollas, zanahorias y tomates. 

La socia está feliz por el préstamo y se compromete a cumplir con los pagos de su cuota.
texts.en:
She is a member of the communal bank "Santa Beatriz". The bank is located in the district of Maranura, which is part of La Convención province in the department of Cusco. 

Victoria works at her business of fruit and vegetable sales. She sells in the market. She sells bananas, oranges, mandarin oranges, and also sells onions, tomatoes, and squash. She has been working for several years in this business and it is going very well. Her dream is to have a shop where she can sell fruits and vegetables. She asks for the loan to purchase oranges, bananas, mandarin oranges and to purchase vegetables such as onions, carrots and tomatoes.

She is happy for this loan and promises to make the payments.

loans.use: to purchase oranges, bananas, mandarin oranges, and to purchase vegetables such as onions, carrots, and tomatoes.

loans.name: Victoria

texts.es:
La socia pertenece al banco comunal “SANTA BEATRIZ”; El banco está ubicado en el distrito de Maranura, perteneciente a la provincia de La Convención y departamento de Cusco.

La socia Victoria se dedica al negocio de tienda de abarrotes, la socia vende productos de primera necesidad como arroz, azucar, leche y galletas, la socia trabaja desde las 8:00 a.m hasta las 7:00 p.m, la socia ya tiene 5 años en este negocio y le va muy bien, el sueño de la socia es ampliar el negocio de tienda de abarrotes. La socia solicita el crédito para comprar arroz, azucar, leche y galletas.

La socia está feliz por el préstamo y se compromete a cumplir con los pagos de su cuota.
texts.en:
The member, Victoria, belongs to Santa Beatriz Communal Bank, located in the Maranura district of the province of La Convención in the department of Cusco.

Victoria makes a living with her grocery store business.  She sells staple items such as rice, sugar, milk, and cookies.  She works from 8 a.m. until 7 p.m.  She already has five years of experience in the business and it's going very well for her.  Her dream is to expand her grocery store business.

Victoria's requesting the loan to buy rice, sugar, milk, and cookies.

She's happy about the loan and promises to make her payments.

loans.use: to buy rice, sugar, milk, and cookies

loans.name: Lydia

texts.en:
Lydia is a resident of Malibay, Pasay, Manila. At the age of 63, she manages her household while operating the business with the help of her children. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for her everyday expenses.

Lydia is a mineral water distributor. What she basically does is buy mineral water in containers from wholesalers, and sell them (5 gallons per container) with a profit. She earns additional income by selling breakfast food items. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of PHP 300 in sales every day.

To help her continue operating her business, she is requesting a PHP 15,000 loan. She will use the loan to buy more stocks of mineral water. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.

Lydia still desires to help out her children in their businesses and hopes to mentor them the best that she can. She meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To buy additional stocks of mineral water to increase her product inventory

loans.name: Paola Andrea

texts.es:
Paola tiene muy claros sus objetivos y uno de ellos es el poder brindarle su hijo una mejor calidad de vida y sacarlo adelante con una excelente educación. Por esta razón se empeña y dedica tiempo a su negocio de venta de comidas rápidas de jueves a domingo todo el día.
Ella aprendió de este oficio gracias a una tía que muy amablemente le enseño.
Ella aprovecha estos conocimientos para progresar y ser más fuerte económicamente.
Ella solicita un préstamo para comprar una carpa, surtido e insumos de trabajo para sus preparaciones y comprar algunas sillas. De esta forma podría ofrecer a sus clientes un mejor servicio y de manera más cómoda, esto se verá reflejado en el aumento de sus ventas y por ende de sus ingresos.
texts.en:
Paola has very clear objectives and one of them is to be able to offer her child a better quality of life and to allow him to get ahead with an excellent education. For this reason, she exerts herself and works in her business of fast food sales from Thursday to Sunday all day.

She learned this work thanks to an aunt who very kindly taught it to her.

She takes advantage of this knowledge to progress and be economically stronger.

She asks for a loan to purchase an awning, stock and work supplies for her preparations and to purchase some chairs. In this way, she could offer her customers better and more comfortable service, which will be reflected in an increase in sales and, as a result, in income.

loans.use: to purchase an awning, and supplies and work materials and to purchase some seats for her business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase construction materials.

loans.name: Juana

texts.es:
La socia pertenece al banco comunal “SANTA BEATRIZ”; El banco está ubicado en el distrito de Maranura, perteneciente a la provincia de La Convención y departamento de Cusco.

La socia Juana  se dedica al negocio de cultivo de frutas, la socia tiene un terreno donde cultiva platanos,cafe,mandarinas y naranjas, la socia trabaja desde las 6:00 a.m hasta las 5:00 p.m,la socia ya tiene varios años en este negocio y le va muy bien, el sueño de la socia es ampliar su terreno de cultivo. La socia solicita le crédito para comprar semillas y fertilizantes.

La socia está feliz por el préstamo y se compromete a cumplir con los pagos de su cuota.
texts.en:
This member belongs to the communal bank "Santa Beatriz". The bank is located in the district of Maranura, which is part of La Convención province and the district of Cusco.

Juana works growing fruit. She has a plot of land where she grows bananas, coffee, mandarin oranges, and oranges. She works from 6:00 am to 5:00 pm. She has been working in this business for a number of years and it is going very well. Her dream is to expand the land she cultivates.  She asks for the loan to purchase seeds and fertilizer.

She is happy for the loan and promises to make her payments.

loans.use: to purchase seeds and fertilizer.

loans.name: Cintia

texts.es:
La socia pertenece al banco comunal “SANTA BEATRIZ”; El banco está ubicado en el distrito de Maranura, perteneciente a la provincia de La Convención y departamento de Cusco.

La socia Cintia tiene 29,es soltera y tiene 1 hijo se dedica al trabajo como ayudante de hogar,la socia limpia,cocina en una casa,la socia trabaja desde las 8:00 a.m hasta las 5:00 p.m,la socia ya tiene varios años en este trabajo,la socia por medio de este trabajo quiere salir adelante.La socia solicita el credito para pagar los estudios de su hijo.

La socia está feliz por el préstamo y se compromete a cumplir con los pagos de su cuota.
texts.en:
The member, Cintia, belongs to Santa Beatriz Communal Bank, located in the Maranura district of the province of La Convención in the department of Cusco.

Cintia, 29, is single and has one child.  She makes a living as a housekeeping helper. She cleans and cooks in a home, working from 8 a.m. until 5 p.m.  She has had this job for several years and she wants to get ahead with her work.

Cintia's requesting the loan to pay for her son's education.

She's happy about the loan and promises to make her payments.

loans.use: to pay for her son's education

loans.name: Edwina

texts.en:
Edwina is a 45-year-old married woman with six children, five of whom attend school. She is a very hard working entrepreneur. 

Edwina's house was destroyed by super typhoon Haiyan which swept through the Philippines last November 8, 2013. She has restarted her business and is committed to regain what she lost. Edwina is taking out a PHP 8,000 housing loan through NWTF to purchase building materials and pay for construction labor to build a house for her family.

Edwina has been with NWTF since 2013 in her pursuit to rise out of poverty. With your help, she will be able to start once more in a new home. In the future, Edwina would like to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase building materials and pay for construction labor

loans.name: Mary Coney

texts.en:
Mary Coney is 42 years old and married with three children.

Mary Coney works hard to provide for her family. She earns a living farming rice and running a general store in the Philippines. She has requested a PHP 29,000 loan through NWTF in order to buy more groceries to sell and fertilizers for her farm.

Mary Coney has been in this business for seven years and has previously received funds through Kiva.

Mary Coney aspires to save enough money to expand her business and continue to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy more groceries to sell and fertilizers for her farm.

loans.name: Gemma

texts.en:
Gemma works hard to support her family. On November 8, 2013, her business and home were wiped out by super typhoon Haiyan.

She has restarted her fish vending business and is now requesting a PHP 8000 housing loan through NWTF to purchase building materials and pay for construction labor so she can build a house for her family. She has been with NWTF since 2012.

With your help, Gemma will be able to rebuild her devastated life sooner.

In the future, Gemma would like to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase building materials and pay for construction labor

loans.name: Gemma

texts.en:
Gemma is 43 years old and married with six children. With two children currently in school, Gemma works very hard to provide for them.

Gemma's business and family home were destroyed by super typhoon Haiyan which swept through the Philippines last November 8, 2013. Gemma has restarted her ready-to-wear clothing business and now needs to provide her family with safe shelter.

Gemma has taken a PHP 5,000 housing loan through NWTF to purchase materials to rebuild her family home.

She is using this loan to purchase building materials and pay for construction labor.

Gemma is committed to rebuilding her devastated life and in future would like to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase building materials and pay for construction labor

loans.name: Irene

texts.en:
Irene is 33 years old and has two children. Irene is married and her two children are in school.

Irene and her family survived super typhoon Haiyan which swept through the Philippines on November 8, 2013, but her business and family home was wiped out. 

Irene is taking out a housing loan amounting PHP 7,000 to purchase building materials and pay for construction labor to build a house for her family. 

Irene has been an NWTF borrower since 2012 and plans to recover through her fish vending business.

With your help, Irene can rebuild her house and rebound from the devastation of super typhoon Haiyan. In future, she would like to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to purchase building materials and pay for construction labor

loans.name: Pierre Richard

texts.en: Pierre Richard lives in the Port-Salut area. He is at the last secondary class in his school. He has usually sold school supplies to classmates so that he could pay cash for school. Now he is coming to us to take out a loan to resell Eneji Pwop products to them and will use the profit to pay for university in the future.

loans.use: To purchase stock for a clean energy business

loans.name: Rosegine

texts.en:
Rosegine, 46, is married with two children.  Her husband works as a laborer but earns just enough for hand-to-mouth needs  and has been striving to earn a living without a stable job. The education of her two children and covering their day-to-day consumption was challenging, so Rosegine decided to open a store selling basic goods.  

They are thankful that they joined Paglaum MPC. With very little capital, they were able to start their sari-sari (general store) business. Their daily sales go the extra mile for the family's needs. They were also able to save with their extra income. They have applied to Paglaum MPC for additional capital of PHP 50,000 to pay for more stock for Rosegine's  sari-sari store. They say they were attracted to Paglaum MPC for its savings and the insurance services of the cooperative. They want to gradually expand their little store and taste a good life someday.

loans.use: to buy more stock for her sari-sari (general) store

loans.name: Ethel

texts.en:
Ethel is 45 years old and a resident of Northern Poblacion, Calamba, Misamis Occidental, Philippines. She has two children, one of whom is in college.  She owns a "sari-sari store" (small grocery store) that forms part of their house, and her neighbors are her customers. 

Since she has a college student to support, she has decided to improve her small business to support her children. She has requested a loan at Paglaum MPC in the amount of 20,000 Php to buy more stock for her sari-sari store. Aside from the financial assistance, she also received add-on benefits like insurance, savings, etc. She hopes that with Paglaum's help, she will become a successful businesswoman someday.

loans.use: to buy more stock for her "sari-sari" (general) store

loans.name: Saturnina

texts.en:
Saturnina  is 65 years old and a resident of Poblacion, Sapang Dalaga, Misamis Occidental, Philippines. She has two adult-aged children.  She owns a "sari-sari store" (small grocery store) that forms part of their house, and her neighbors are her customers. 

She has decided to improve her small business to support their needs. So she has requested a loan at Paglaum MPC in the amount of 10,000 Php to restock her sari-sari store with basic goods. Aside from the financial assistance, she also received add-on benefits like insurance, savings, etc. She hopes that with Paglaum's help, she will become a successful businesswoman someday.

loans.use: to restock her sari-sari store with basic goods

loans.name: Jacie

texts.en:
Jacie is a married woman with three children. She is a very hard-working entrepreneur. Jacie is 34 years old and has two children who are currently in school.

Jacie's house was destroyed by super typhoon Haiyan which swept through the Philippines on November 8, 2013. She has restarted her fish vending business and is committed to regaining what she lost. Jacie is taking out a PHP 6,500 housing loan through NWTF to purchase building materials and pay for construction labor to build a house for her family.

Jacie has been with NWTF since 2012 in her pursuit to rise out of poverty. With your help, she will be able to start once more in a new home. In the future, Jacie would like to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to school.

loans.use: to purchase building materials and pay for construction labor

loans.name: Arlene

texts.en:
As a married mother of three children, Arlene works hard to support her family.

She has a tricycle transportation business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from fish vending. Arlene is borrowing PHP 50,000 through NWTF in order to buy spare parts for her tricycle.

Arlene has been sustaining her business activities through her past 14 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy spare parts for her tricycle.

loans.name: Magdalena

texts.en:
Magdalena is 31 years old and married with one child.

Magdalena works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 25,000 loan through NWTF in order to buy more groceries like laundry soap, snack food, canned goods, etc.

Magdalena has borrowed and repaid 14 loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for 14 years and also earns an income from dressmaking.

Magdalena aspires to save enough money to expand her business and repair her family's home.

loans.use: to buy more groceries like laundry soap, snack food, canned goods, etc

loans.name: Joanne

texts.en:
Joanne is a resident of Malibay, Pasay, Philippines and she is married to Enrico. She and her husband manage their household while operating the business. They work hard to provide income for their everyday needs.

Joanne maintains a direct selling business. She sells clothing, footwear, undergarments, cosmetics and other products through the popular direct selling brands like Avon, Fuller Life, Natasha, Boardwalk, Marikina Shoe Exchange, and others. A customer's order is bought in cash by the dealer and then given to the customer with a one-month-to-pay credit. Dealer’s prices are lower than those in the catalogue, and these are the profits that dealers are investing on as their income. Joanne's regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of Php 2000 in sales every week.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php 15,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy additional supplies and merchandise products like shampoo, cologne, deodorant, perfume, soap, fabric softener, undergarments and other products needed in her business. 

Joanne dreams of having her own stall and hopes to become financially stable through her direct selling business. She meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her life and business every week and draw strength and inspiration from the fellowship and the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for additional merchandise like clothing, footwear, undergarments, and cosmetics needed in her business.

loans.name: Maricar

texts.en: Maricar is 18 years of age and now ready for her college course. However she needs Php 40,000 for her tuition fee, thus she is requesting a loan from KIVA lenders thru ASKI. According to Maricar, it will be very helpful if lenders will provide her requested loan, for, with education, she can definitely have a decent job in the future. And with that she is very optimistic that she can assist her family financially.

loans.use: To pay her tuition fee

loans.name: Sunshine

texts.en:
Sunshine previously accessed a 15,000 PHP loan that she used to buy additional stocks of toys and other products. Her earnings were a big help for the education of her children and in their personal, household and business expenditures.

She would now like to apply for a 17,000 PHP loan to buy additional stocks of toys and other products needed in her business. The more items displayed at the store, the better. More items to sell will result in better profit. Her profits from business will definitely help her to sustain her daily needs and cover the educational expenses of her children. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Sunshine hopes to grow and expand her buy-and-sell business so that she can cover their everyday needs, especially her children's education. She meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week. This is where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies. 

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for more candies and toys  to expand her product inventory.

loans.name: Riza

texts.en:
Riza is 38 years old, married, and has five children who are all attending school. She is a very hard-working entrepreneur. 

Riza has a fish-vending business in the Philippines. She requested a PHP 29,000 loan through NWTF in order to buy more fish to sell.

Riza has been in this business for ten years. In the future, Riza would like to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy more fish to sell.

loans.name: Antonio

texts.en:
Antonio works hard to support her family. On November 8, 2013, her business and home were wiped out by super typhoon Haiyan.

She has restarted her business and has been in NWTF since 2008. Now she is requesting a PHP 8,000 housing loan through NWTF to purchase building materials and pay for construction labor so she can build a house for her family.

With your help, Antonio will be able to rebuild her devastated life sooner.

Antonio would like to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to purchase building materials and pay for construction labor

loans.name: Berny

texts.en:
Berny previously accessed a 15,000 PHP loan that she used for purchasing necessary supplies and materials for her business. Her earnings were a big help for her personal, household, and business expenditures. She would like to apply for another 10,000 PHP loan to buy new supplies and products needed for her massage service. Her profits from business will definitely help sustain her daily needs and other expenses. She looks forward to this financial assistance with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Berny dreams to have her own clinic and hopes to renovate their house. She meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies. 

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for supplies needed in her business.

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en: Teresita is 61 years old, married and has four children. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur.  Teresita has a fishing business in the Philippines. She has requested a PHP 19,000 loan amount through NWTF in order to buy fishing gear and other equipment. Teresita has been in this business for 30 years. In the future, Teresita would like to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy fishing gear and other equipment.

loans.name: Jill

texts.en: Jill works hard to support her family. On November 8, 2013, her business and home were wiped out by Super Typhoon Haiyan. She has restarted her fish vending business and been in NWTF since 2008.  She is now requesting a PHP 6,000 housing loan through NWTF to purchase building materials and pay for construction labor, so she could build a house for her family. With your help, Jill will be able to rebuild her devastated life sooner. Jill would like to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to purchase building materials and pay for construction labor.

loans.name: Gloria

texts.en:
Gloria is very thankful for the loan assistance previously extended to her. She used the loan to purchase more quantities and varieties of grocery items and products needed in her business. Her earnings were a big help in her children’s education and in the family's personal, household and business expenditures.

Gloria would like to apply for another loan of 50,000 Philippine pesos to buy groceries, toiletries, beverages and other products to add to her inventory. The more items displayed in the store the better. More items to sell will result in better profits. Her profits from the business will definitely help sustain her family’s daily needs and her children’s education expenses. Gloria looks forward to this financial assistance with gladness and thankfulness in her heart. 

Gloria dreams of giving her children a better future and hopes that her business will always meet their everyday expenses. Every week, she meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her life and business and draw strength and inspiration from the fellowship and the Word of God, which she studies.

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and repay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: To buy groceries, toiletries, beverages and other products to add to her inventory.

loans.name: Elena

texts.en:
Elena is a 63-year-old resident of Malibay, Pasay, Philippines and she is married to Leonardo. She and her husband manage their household while operating the business. They work hard for their family and to provide income for their everyday needs.

Elena maintains a direct selling business. She sells clothing, footwear, undergarments, cosmetics and other products through popular direct selling brands like Avon, Fuller life, Natasha, Boardwalk, Marikina Shoe Exchange, and other direct selling brands. A customer's order is bought in cash by the dealer and then given to the customer with a one-month-to-pay credit. Dealer’s prices are lower than those in the catalogue, and these are the profits that dealers are investing on as their income. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of PHP 2,000 in sales every week.

To help her continue the operations of her business, she is requesting a PHP 25,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy additional supplies and merchandise products like shampoo, cologne, deodorant, perfume, soap, fabric softener, undergarments, and other products needed in her business. Elena also maintains a variety store business and house rental business while his husband works as a tricycle operator.

Elena hopes that her family will always be healthy and dreams to progress in her business. She meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her life and business every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the fellowship and the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for additional supplies and merchandise products like clothing, footwear, undergarments, and cosmetics.

loans.name: Judy

texts.en:
Judy is 40 years old and married with three children. With two children currently in school, Judy works very hard to provide for them. Her business and family home were destroyed by Super Typhoon Haiyan, which swept through the Philippines last November 8, 2013. Judy has restarted her food vending business and now needs to provide her family with safe shelter.

Judy has taken a PHP 7,000 housing loan through NWTF to purchase materials to rebuild her family home. She is using this loan to purchase building materials and pay for construction labor. Judy is committed to rebuild her devastated life and would like to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to purchase building materials and pay for construction labor.

loans.name: Juliet

texts.en:
Juliet is 31 years old, married and has one child in school. She and her family survived super typhoon Haiyan, which swept through the Philippines last November 8, 2013, but her business and family home were wiped out. 

Juliet is taking out a housing loan of 9,000 Philippines pesos (PHP) to buy building materials and pay for construction labor to build a new house for her family. She has been an NWTF borrower since 2012 and plans to recover through her general store business.

With your help, Juliet can rebuild her house and rebound from the devastation of super typhoon Haiyan. She would like to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy building materials and pay for construction labor

loans.name: Gina

texts.en: As a married mother of four children, Gina works hard to support her family. She has a fish vending business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from raising pigs. Gina is borrowing PHP 15,000 through NWTF in order to buy more fish to sell for her fish vending business. Gina has been sustaining her business activities through her past seven loans from NWTF, and more recently through Kiva. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy more fish to sell.

loans.name: Elma

texts.en: Elma is 44 years old, and married with two children who are both in school. Elma works very hard to provide for them. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 24,000 loan through NWTF in order to buy more items like detergent, snack foods, cooking oil and other groceries. Elma has been in this business for eight years.  In the future, Elma would like to save enough money to expand her business and continue to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy more items like detergent, snack foods, cooking oil and other groceries.

loans.name: Marycel

texts.en: Marycel is 40 years old and married with two children, and both of them are in school. Marycel works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 15,000 loan through NWTF in order to buy more groceries to sell. Marycel has been in this business for three years and has previously received funds through Kiva.  She aspires to save enough money to expand her business and repair her family's home.

loans.use: to buy more groceries to sell.

loans.name: Leonora

texts.en:
Leonora, 36, is a married woman with six children. Four of her children are in school. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur.

Leonora's house was destroyed by super typhoon Haiyan, which swept through the Philippines on November 8, 2013. She has restarted her fish vending business and is committed to regaining what she lost. 

Leonora is taking out a housing loan of 6,000 Philippine pesos through the Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation. She will use the loan to purchase building materials and pay for construction labour to build a house for her family.

Leonora has been with NWTF since 2008 in her pursuit to rise out of poverty. With your help, she will be able to start once more, in a new home. In the future, Leonora would like to save enough money to afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase building materials and pay for construction labour

loans.name: Celna

texts.en:
Celna is 50 years old, married and has six children, two of whom are in school. 

Celna is in the agricultural business, raising pigs in the Philippines. She requested a 15,000 PHP loan through NWTF in order to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs. Celna has been raising pigs for 20 years now, and has borrowed 10 times in the past from NWTF to sustain it.

In the future, Celna would like to save enough money to expand her business and repair her family's home.

loans.use: to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs.

loans.name: Ma. Beguilla

texts.en:
Ma. Beguilla works hard to support her family. On November 8, 2013, her business and home were wiped out by super typhoon Haiyan.

She has restarted her business and been with NWTF since 2013 and is now requesting an 8,500 PHP housing loan through NWTF to purchase building materials and pay for construction labor so she could build a house for her family. With your help, Ma. Beguilla will be able to rebuild her devastated life sooner.

Ma. Beguilla would like to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to purchase building materials and pay for construction labor

loans.name: Estrella

texts.en: As a married mother of eight children, Estrella works hard to support her family. She has an agriculture business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from fish vending.  Estrella is borrowing PHP 22,000 through NWTF in order to buy medicines and vaccines for her pigs. Estrella has been sustaining her business activities through her past 30 loans from NWTF and more recently, through Kiva. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save enough money to expand her business and repair her family's home.

loans.use: to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs.

loans.name: Myrna

texts.en:
Myrna is thankful for the financial assistance extended to her as she was able to buy more products for her variety store. Her income from business is assisting their everyday household expenditures. She and her husband are working hard to provide for their everyday needs. She also has a tricycle for additional income.

Myrna would like to apply for another 8,000 PHP loan for her to buy groceries, toiletries, beverages and other products to add in her current inventory. The more items displayed at the store, the better. More items to sell will result in better profit. Her profits from business will definitely help her to sustain her daily needs. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Myrna dreams to be more successful in business and hopes to have another tricycle unit. She meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for grocery items and products needed in her business.
